bestBHT.bht: A chorus of voices cried out, desiring the crucifixion of Christ. Among them were those who had once celebrated Him as the Son of David during the triumphal entry. Though unmentioned by Matthew and Mark, Luke reveals that this cry had been made before. This repetition of their plea emphasizes the fervent intensity with which they sought Jesus' crucifixion. For a more detailed examination, see the discussion on Matthew 27:23.

Henry Alford: 13.] again only refers to “cried out;” see ver. 8, where this is implied in “began to desire:”—they had not cried out this before.
Archibald T. Robertson: There was a chorus and a hubbub of confused voices all demanding crucifixion for Christ.
Some of the voices beyond a doubt had joined in the hallelujahs to the Son of David in the triumphal entry.
See on Matthew 27:23 for discussion of Mark 15:14.
John Gill: And they cried out again, crucify him. For they had cried so once before, though Matthew and Mark relate it not, yet Luke does, Luke 23:21.

bhtAttempts.bht: The scene in Mark 15:13 is filled with a cacophony of voices, all demanding the crucifixion of Christ. Some of these voices were ones that had previously joined in the hallelujahs to the Son of David during the triumphal entry. Although Matthew and Mark do not explicitly mention it, Luke recounts that they had cried out for Christ's crucifixion once before. This repetition of their demand further emphasizes the intensity of their desire for Jesus to be crucified. For an in-depth discussion on this verse, one can refer to Matthew 27:23.

A chorus of voices erupted, crying out for Christ's crucifixion in an intense clamor. Amongst the crowd were those who had previously joined in triumphant hallelujahs honoring the Son of David. Although not explicitly mentioned by Matthew and Mark, Luke reveals that this was not the first time they had demanded Christ's crucifixion. This repeated cry underscores their fervent desire to see Jesus on the cross. For a deeper understanding, one can refer to the discussion in Matthew 27:23.

A hubbub of voices filled the air as the multitude cried out for Christ's crucifixion. Some of those voices had previously joined in the triumphant hallelujahs during the Son of David's entry. Luke reveals that this was not their first cry, although Matthew and Mark do not mention it. The repetition of their demand reveals their unwavering determination to see Jesus crucified. For further discussion, see Matthew 27:23.

A chorus of voices cried out, desiring the crucifixion of Christ. Among them were those who had once celebrated Him as the Son of David during the triumphal entry. Though unmentioned by Matthew and Mark, Luke reveals that this cry had been made before. This repetition of their plea emphasizes the fervent intensity with which they sought Jesus' crucifixion. For a more detailed examination, see the discussion on Matthew 27:23.

Amidst a dissonance of voices, a passionate multitude cried out for Christ's crucifixion. Interestingly, some of these very voices had once joined in joyful praises during His triumphal entry as the Son of David. Although unmentioned by Matthew and Mark, Luke sheds light on the fact that this cry had been made previously. The recurrence of their demand underscored their unwavering determination to see Jesus nailed to the cross. A thorough exploration of this can be found in the discussion surrounding Matthew 27:23.
